legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

Step 2: The *Mottley* rule, focusing solely on the plaintiff's complaint for §1331, is a simplification.  Cases often involve interwoven state and federal issues. Step 3:  While interpreting *Mottley* as applying to Article III would significantly restrict federal court power, it's not a complete restriction. Step 4: The *Consolidated* case example highlights a potential drastic restriction.  While alternative jurisdictional bases might exist, a strict *Mottley* interpretation of Article III would eliminate a significant avenue for federal court review of cases involving federal defenses or counterclaims, leaving such matters solely to state courts in many instances.  The example is illustrative, though not exhaustive.

Step 5:  State courts do not have *final* authority on federal law questions, even under a strict *Mottley* interpretation of Article III. The Supreme Court can review these decisions via certiorari, albeit this is discretionary. The statement overstates the implications.

Step 6:  *Osborn*'s "ingredient" test, while broader than *Mottley*, lacks precision.  The vagueness of "ingredient" leaves room for judicial discretion and potential inconsistency in application.  This is a valid criticism of the *Osborn* standard.

Step 7: While Congress *could* amend 28 U.S.C. §1331, political realities make this unlikely.  The potential for unintended consequences, including increased litigation and jurisdictional disputes, would likely outweigh the benefits of a change.

Step 8: Congress's non-repudiation of *Mottley* is likely due to a combination of factors, including its perceived clarity (despite its limitations), its preventative effect on jurisdictional manipulation, and the political difficulty of changing established precedent.  The provided explanation is incomplete.

Step 9: The Supreme Court's ongoing interpretation and refinement of "arising under" in both Article III and §1331 contexts demonstrates the dynamic nature of this area of law. The analysis should acknowledge this ongoing evolution and its implications.

Step 10: In Eleanor v. Franklin, the federal statute is a defense, not the basis of the claim.  This limits the applicability of §1331's "well-pleaded complaint" rule.  However, Article III's broader scope, as interpreted in *Osborn*, would encompass this case because the federal statute is a substantive ingredient.

Step 11: Supplemental jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. §1367 is relevant.  Once a substantial federal question is presented (as it is in the defense), the court could exercise supplemental jurisdiction over the state law breach of contract claim.

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

However, this power is not unlimited.  Significant restrictions could face challenges based on due process concerns, particularly if they severely limit access to justice for certain classes of plaintiffs or claims, or if they undermine the effective enforcement of federal rights.

This would restrict the jurisdiction of federal district courts by excluding cases involving smaller amounts in controversy, regardless of whether they arise under federal law.  This could disproportionately affect individuals with smaller claims but significant federal interests, limiting their access to federal courts.  Further, it could incentivize strategic behavior by defendants to manipulate the amount in controversy to avoid federal court.

The $75,000.01 limit could create a significant barrier to federal court for many individuals with valid federal claims, potentially undermining the purpose of providing a federal forum for resolving such disputes.  This restriction could also disproportionately impact certain plaintiffs or types of claims, raising potential equal protection concerns. The balance between Congress's power to define jurisdiction and the need to ensure fair access to federal courts for the enforcement of federal rights is critical. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. Step 5:  Option A is too simplistic. Adding a new legal theory, even if based on the same facts, can be disruptive and inefficient, especially later in the process. Option B is incorrect because while the court can consider counsel's diligence, it's not the sole basis for denial.  Option C is incorrect as the possibility of recovery on one claim doesn't preclude adding another, but the additional burden and cost must be considered. Option D, while generally favoring amendments, overlooks the potential for significant prejudice and inefficiency caused by the late addition of a substantially different legal theory.

Step 6: The court must consider its inherent authority to manage its docket and balance the competing interests of justice, efficiency, and fairness.  Granting the amendment could burden the opposing party with additional costs and delays, potentially outweighing the benefit of deciding the case on the merits.  The potential for strategic gamesmanship by plaintiffs in delaying the assertion of alternative theories must also be considered.

Step 7:  The policy goals of Rule 15(a)(2) – promoting resolution on the merits – must be weighed against the equally important policy goals of preventing prejudice and ensuring efficient case management.  In this case, the significant additional discovery and potential delay caused by adding the negligence claim six months into discovery, along with the lack of explanation for the initial oversight, weigh against granting the amendment.

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

The court must determine whether the parties' actions, including arguments, cross-examination, and closing statements, demonstrated an implied agreement to litigate the assumption of risk defense. Simply because evidence is relevant to multiple issues does not mean the unpleaded issue was implicitly tried.

Comparative negligence focuses on the degree of fault, while assumption of risk focuses on voluntary acceptance of a known risk. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

Step 4: Option A (records at Advanced Testing) is a secondary, but potentially valid, objection.  Plante may not be required to produce documents in another party's possession.  However, this objection is secondary to the primary flaw: the lack of reasonable particularity. Option B (records not in Arizona) is also relevant regarding jurisdiction and the court's power to compel production.  However, the primary issue is the overbreadth of the request itself. Option C (electronic records) highlights a significant aspect of the burden, but the core problem is not merely the *type* of records requested but the *lack of specification* regarding the *relevance* of those records.

Step 5: The lack of reasonable particularity is the *most compelling* objection, but it doesn't preclude other valid objections.  The court may consider all valid arguments when ruling on the request.  While negotiation and stipulation between parties are encouraged, the initial request itself is fatally flawed due to its overbreadth and lack of reasonable particularity.

Step 6:  The analysis distinguishes between "overly broad" and "lacking reasonable particularity."  While related, they are distinct concepts. A request can be overly broad even if it describes categories with some particularity if the scope is disproportionate to the needs of the case.  Lack of reasonable particularity directly violates Rule 34; overbreadth is a consequence that often flows from that violation.

Step 7: The analysis acknowledges the challenges of electronic discovery and retrieving data from diverse sources, including deleted files.  However, it emphasizes that these challenges do not justify an unbounded request.  The request needs specific parameters to limit the scope and burden.

Step 8: The analysis considers proportionality and the need to balance the parties' interests.  The current request fails this test; the burden significantly outweighs the likely benefit given its lack of specificity.

Step 9: The severity of the alleged injuries and potential damages are relevant to the overall scope of discovery, but they do not justify an unlimited request.  A narrower, more focused request could still yield relevant information without undue burden.

Step 10:  Plante Laboratories may have a duty to preserve relevant evidence, even if held by a third party.  However, this duty does not automatically obligate Plante to produce *all* documents from the third party without a targeted and reasonably particular request.

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. Step 1: The motion for summary judgment should be granted only if there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law (Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a)).  Crucible argues that Jericho was not acting within the scope of his employment when the accident occurred.

Step 2: Crucible supports its motion with Gomez's affidavit, stating Jericho used the van to go to the hospital after receiving a call about his mother.  This, on its face, suggests Jericho was on a personal errand. However, this affidavit alone does not definitively establish that Jericho was *entirely* outside the scope of his employment during the accident.  The affidavit addresses Jericho's initial reason for using the vehicle, not necessarily his actions immediately before or during the accident.

Step 3: Tang's response includes an affidavit from a witness stating Jericho swerved into the opposite lane before the accident. This directly contradicts Crucible's assertion that Jericho was solely focused on a personal emergency.  This creates a genuine dispute of material fact regarding Jericho's actions immediately preceding the accident.  A reasonable jury could conclude that even if Jericho initially began a personal errand, he negligently operated the vehicle while still utilizing it, potentially bringing his actions back within the scope of his employment (depending on the jurisdiction's interpretation of "frolic and detour").

Step 4:  The fact that Jericho was using a company van at the time of the accident raises questions about potential vicarious liability for Crucible, regardless of whether Jericho's actions were strictly within the scope of employment.  Negligent entrustment is another potential liability, particularly if Crucible knew or should have known that Jericho was an unsafe driver.

Step 5: Tang's doctor's affidavit, while seemingly addressing only damages, is a material fact related to the extent of Tang's injuries, a necessary element for determining the amount of damages.  This evidence is relevant even if the issue of liability is disputed.

Step 6:  The witness testimony and the potential for vicarious liability or negligent entrustment create genuine disputes of material fact, preventing summary judgment.  The court cannot resolve these disputes based solely on the Gomez affidavit.  The evidence presented by Tang creates a sufficient factual dispute to warrant a trial.


Step 7: Considering all presented evidence, a reasonable jury could differ on whether Jericho was acting within the scope of his employment at the time of the accident.  This genuine dispute of material fact, along with the disputed issue of Jericho's negligence, makes summary judgment inappropriate.

Step 8:  Summary judgment is a drastic measure and should only be granted when there is no genuine dispute of material fact.  The presented evidence demonstrates a genuine dispute of material fact, making summary judgment for Crucible improper.

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

Step 1: Consolidated's motion to dismiss, accompanied by an affidavit containing evidence outside the pleadings, constitutes a "speaking motion" under Rule 12(b)(6).

Step 2:  According to Rule 12(d), when matters outside the pleadings are presented and not excluded by the court in a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the motion must be treated as one for summary judgment under Rule 56.

Step 3:  The court must afford both parties a reasonable opportunity to present all pertinent material.  This includes allowing Fenske to present countervailing evidence to refute Consolidated's affidavit asserting Shea was not working at the time of the accident.  The affidavit itself is not automatically dispositive; its admissibility and weight will be assessed under the summary judgment standard.  There's a possibility the affidavit constitutes inadmissible hearsay.

Step 4:  The court will then apply the Rule 56 standard, determining whether there is a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether Shea was acting within the scope of his employment at the time of the accident. This involves considering whether Fenske can present sufficient evidence to create a genuine dispute on this issue, even if the evidence presented by Consolidated initially suggests otherwise.

Step 5:  The mere existence of a valid legal claim in Fenske's complaint doesn't automatically prevent dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) when converted to a Rule 56 motion. The focus shifts to whether there's sufficient evidence to support the claim.  The plaintiff bears the initial burden of establishing a prima facie case; however, the defendant must also demonstrate the absence of a genuine issue of material fact to prevail on summary judgment.

Step 6:  The timing of the motion (after an answer has been filed) doesn't preclude conversion to summary judgment under Rule 12(d).  Rule 56(b) permits a defendant to file a summary judgment motion at any time until after the close of discovery.

Step 7:  The court must ensure the plaintiff receives adequate notice and opportunity to respond to the converted summary judgment motion, thereby mitigating potential prejudice.  This includes a reasonable time to present countervailing evidence and address the issues raised in the affidavit.

Step 8:  The court should consider the possibility of the affidavit being inadmissible hearsay. If deemed inadmissible, it won't be considered in the summary judgment analysis, potentially altering the outcome.

Step 9:  The court could potentially exclude the matters outside the pleadings under Rule 12(d), thus avoiding conversion to summary judgment altogether if it finds the evidence insufficient to warrant such conversion.  However, this is less likely given the straightforward nature of the evidence presented.


Step 10:  The court must differentiate between the Rule 12(b)(6) standard (legal sufficiency of the complaint) and the Rule 56 standard (genuine issue of material fact).  The latter requires consideration of evidence beyond the complaint.

Step 11:  The court should not automatically grant summary judgment based solely on Consolidated's affidavit.  There needs to be a full evaluation of whether Fenske can present evidence to create a genuine dispute of material fact.

Step 1: The provided text explains that a directed verdict (judgment as a matter of law) is appropriate when the plaintiff fails to present sufficient evidence to establish a legally sufficient evidentiary basis for each element of their claim.  The judge assesses whether a rational jury *could* find for the plaintiff, not whether the judge *would* find for the plaintiff.

Step 2: The plaintiff, Powers, is suing Dr. Vicaro for medical negligence.  Negligence requires proof of duty, breach, causation, and damages.

Step 3: Powers' evidence shows she had arm pain, received treatment, her arm worsened, and she suffered damages (loss of job). However, there is no evidence presented regarding whether Dr. Vicaro owed her a duty of care, breached that duty, or whether the breach caused her damages.  The evidence only shows correlation, not causation.

Step 4:  The plaintiff has failed to present evidence sufficient to establish essential elements of her negligence claim (duty, breach, and causation). A rational jury could not find for the plaintiff based on the evidence presented.

Step 5: Therefore, the judge should grant the defendant's motion for judgment as a matter of law because the plaintiff has not met her burden of production on essential elements of her claim. Option B is incorrect because the defendant's case is irrelevant to whether the plaintiff has met her initial burden of production. Option D is incorrect because the motion for judgment as a matter of law can be made at the close of the plaintiff's case. :
Step 1: The standard for granting a directed verdict (judgment as a matter of law) is that there is no legally sufficient evidentiary basis for a reasonable jury to find for the non-moving party.  While this is the general principle reflected in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 50(a), the specific application can vary slightly depending on the jurisdiction and the specific facts of the case.  The judge must consider whether a reasonable jury could find for the plaintiff based on the evidence presented, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the plaintiff and drawing all reasonable inferences in the plaintiff's favor.

Step 2: Powers is suing Dr. Vicaro for medical negligence.  To prevail, she must prove: (1) a duty of care owed by Dr. Vicaro; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) causation (that the breach caused her injuries); and (4) damages.  Medical negligence claims often require expert testimony to establish the standard of care, breach, and causation.

Step 3: Powers' evidence shows arm pain, treatment by Dr. Vicaro, worsening arm condition, and resulting damages (job loss).  While this evidence establishes damages, it does not, on its own, establish duty, breach, or causation.  The evidence is correlational, not causational.  It does not, without more, show that Dr. Vicaro's treatment fell below the standard of care or that his actions directly caused the worsening of her arm condition.  Circumstantial evidence might support inferences, but at this stage, the evidence is insufficient to support a finding of negligence.  The absence of expert testimony to establish the standard of care and causation is a significant gap.

Step 4:  A reasonable jury *could not*, based solely on the evidence presented by the plaintiff, find for Powers.  While juries can draw reasonable inferences, they cannot engage in speculation or conjecture.  The presented evidence, lacking expert testimony on crucial elements, does not provide a legally sufficient evidentiary basis for a finding of negligence.  The possibility of inferences is not enough to overcome the insufficiency of evidence on essential elements.

Step 5:  Therefore, the judge should grant the defendant's motion for judgment as a matter of law.  The plaintiff has failed to meet her burden of production on essential elements of her negligence claim. While the defendant's case and cross-examination could potentially strengthen the plaintiff's case, the motion is properly decided based on the evidence presented *by the plaintiff* at the close of her case.  The judge is not required to consider what the defendant might present. The plaintiff has the opportunity to address any deficiencies in her case through rebuttal evidence, but at the close of her case, the evidence is insufficient.

### Updated Reasoning Steps:
Step 1: Rule 50(a) allows for a directed verdict (judgment as a matter of law) if the evidence is insufficient to support a verdict for the non-moving party.  While a lack of evidence to meet the burden of production on any element is a common ground, it's not the only one.  A directed verdict can also be granted if the evidence, even if sufficient to meet the burden of production, is so overwhelmingly in favor of the moving party that no reasonable jury could find for the non-moving party.

Step 2: The "burden of production" requires the plaintiff to present enough evidence to allow a rational jury to find in their favor. This necessitates consideration of the evidence's strength, credibility, and whether it directly or circumstantially supports each element of the claim.  The judge assesses this, not whether *they* would be convinced, but whether a reasonable jury *could* be.  The judge also considers the weight of the evidence, even though the final weight assessment is for the jury.

Step 3: The judge assesses the burden of production; the jury assesses the burden of proof (preponderance of the evidence).  However, the judge's evaluation of the burden of production isn't entirely separate from the jury's role. A judge might deny a motion for judgment as a matter of law even if they personally believe the plaintiff's case is weak, as long as a reasonable jury could find for the plaintiff.  Conversely, a judge might grant the motion even if some evidence supports the plaintiff, if that evidence is so weak or unconvincing that no reasonable jury could find for the plaintiff.

The judge must determine if sufficient evidence exists for a reasonable jury to find for the plaintiff.  The burden of proof is for the jury to decide after the burden of production hurdle is cleared.

Step 5: Option C is incorrect. While the jury's deliberations inherently involve assessing the evidence, they don't explicitly determine whether the burden of production is met. legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

If the appellate court affirms the JMOL but finds error in the conditional new trial grant, it could vacate the conditional new trial grant while upholding the JMOL.  Conversely, if the appellate court reverses the JMOL, the conditional new trial would then become effective.

If based on a minor procedural error, appealability might be deferred until after a new trial.

Step 11: The conditional grant of a new trial could be interpreted as a non-final, interlocutory order preventing immediate appeal of the JMOL, especially if the conditional grant is based on a significant procedural error requiring a complete do-over.

Step 12: The appellate court could modify the lower court’s decision, affecting the finality of the judgment and the appealability of both orders.  For example, it might vacate the conditional new trial grant and modify the JMOL.

Step 13: The legal reasoning must fully address Rule 50(c)'s complexities and the varied interpretations of "final judgment" and "conditional grant."  The analysis needs to consider the interplay of various factors and potential outcomes.

Step 14: The reasoning should acknowledge conflicting precedents or differing interpretations of Rule 50(c) across jurisdictions. The analysis must be grounded in the specific jurisdiction's precedents.

Step 15: The analysis must acknowledge other procedural rules and legal doctrines influencing the appealability of the JMOL and the conditional new trial grant.  This includes rules governing interlocutory appeals and the final judgment rule.

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

legal_scenarios.Context: Under federal diversity jurisdiction a citizen of one state may sue a citizen of another in federal court, even though her claim arises under state law, if she has a colorable claim for more than $75,000. The state citizenship of a person—as opposed to that of a corporation—is determined by her domicile, that is, the most recent state where she has (1) resided with (2) the intent to remain indefinitely. The ‘‘residence’’ requirement is easily satisfied. Staying overnight in a hotel or a tent will establish ‘‘residence’’ in a state. It is the intent-to-remain-indefinitely prong that gives students problems. A person intends to remain indefinitely in a state if she is residing in the state on an open-ended basis, without the intent to leave at a definite time or on the occurrence of a definite event. You don’t have to swear allegiance forever to a state to acquire domicile there; you only need to reside there ‘‘indefinitely,’’ that is, on an open-ended basis. If a party is living in a state without definite plans to leave, the domicile test regards that state as her ‘‘home.’’ She is there, not as a visitor, but as a citizen. She is, psychologically speaking, at home there, rather than passing through. She may choose to move on, as we all may, but at the moment she has no plans to do so. Remember that, until the two prongs coincide in a new state, your old domicile continues, whether you plan to return to that state or not. If Acari, from Hawaii, leaves for a one-year job acting in a play in California, planning to go to New York afterwards, he remains domiciled in Hawaii, even if he swears that he will never return to Hawaii. He hasn’t acquired a domicile in California, because he doesn’t plan to stay there indefinitely. He hasn’t acquired one in New York either, since he doesn’t reside there yet. Domicile doctrine abhors a vacuum, so it holds that Acari keeps his Hawaii domicile until the two prerequisites come together in another state. In analyzing the question below, assume that the court applies the reside-with-intent-to-remain-indefinitely test, and consider where Marla has established a residence with the requisite ‘‘indefinite’’ intent

Step 1: The core principle of collateral estoppel is to prevent relitigation of issues already decided.  However,  it only applies when the factfinder in the first case *actually decided* the issue, not merely heard evidence on it. legal_scenarios.updated_reasoning:
:
Step 1: The core principle of collateral estoppel is that a party should not be allowed to relitigate an issue that has already been fully and fairly litigated and decided against them.  This principle applies regardless of whether the subsequent suit involves the same parties (mutual collateral estoppel) or a new party (non-mutual collateral estoppel). However,  non-mutual collateral estoppel is more cautiously applied, requiring a showing that the issue was fully and fairly litigated in the first action and that applying estoppel is fair to all parties.

Step 2: In *Parklane Hosiery*, the Supreme Court established that non-mutual collateral estoppel is permissible in federal courts, but only under circumstances ensuring fairness.  This generally means the party against whom estoppel is asserted had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issue in the first case.  The court also considers whether the prior judgment was based on a full trial on the merits.

Step 3:  In the Gotchall/Carmichael case, the issue is whether Faithful's brochure promised a 15% return. Gotchall litigated this issue and lost.  The judge found the brochure did not *guarantee* a particular return.  Crucially, the question is whether this finding was necessary to the judgment.  If the judge could have dismissed the case on other grounds, the finding on the brochure's promise is not necessarily conclusive for collateral estoppel purposes.

Step 4:  Carmichael, not being a party to the first suit, cannot be bound by mutual collateral estoppel.  However, the court must consider whether non-mutual collateral estoppel applies.  This requires analyzing whether the issue was fully and fairly litigated in Gotchall's case and whether applying estoppel to Carmichael would be fair.  The fact that the judge found ambiguity in the brochure's language is significant. This ambiguity suggests that the finding against Gotchall may not be dispositive on the question of whether the brochure *promised* a 15% return.  A different fact-finder might reasonably interpret the ambiguity differently.

Step 5: Applying non-mutual collateral estoppel would be unfair to Carmichael because the finding on the brochure's promise was not necessarily essential to the judgment in Gotchall's case.  The judge's decision might have rested on other aspects of Gotchall's claim, even if she addressed the brochure's language.  Furthermore, allowing non-mutual collateral estoppel here could lead to inconsistent judgments, as other investors could bring similar suits with potentially different outcomes.  This undermines the policy goals of collateral estoppel.

Step 6: Therefore, because Carmichael was not a party to the prior action, and because the finding regarding the brochure's promise was not necessarily essential to the judgment in Gotchall’s case and potentially ambiguous, applying collateral estoppel against him would be inappropriate.
